"Rob Peace," a film that premiered in 2024, was one I regrettably missed in theaters, but I was able to catch it on Netflix. The movie features the talented Mary J. Blige in a key role.

From the moment I started watching, I was captivated by the story. It revolves around a father who stands trial for murder, while his exceptionally bright son seeks a way to secure his father's freedom as he navigates college life. However, the father’s frustration grows, as he yearns for release sooner than his son's efforts can deliver.

The narrative centers on the young man, named Rob—short for Robert—who faces significant challenges as he strives to earn his degree. Along the way, he discovers a knack for chemistry, which leads him into some difficult situations.

In general, the film was an engaging experience. However, it felt overly lengthy; there were about 20 to 25 minutes that I found myself skipping, as they contained excessive dialogue that didn’t contribute meaningfully to the plot or character development. It felt like filler that unnecessarily extended the film’s runtime.

The film’s conclusion is quite emotional and difficult to watch. While I had anticipated Mary J. Blige to play a more substantial role, she delivered her performance well, showcasing her talents as both an actress and a singer.

Now, regarding the lead actor, I found his character to be well-crafted, but his portrayal leaned too heavily into a stereotype. While I don't mean to sound harsh, he came across as overly tough or "thuggish," which detracted from the character’s genuine struggles. I believe he could have better represented someone emerging from a challenging background trying to improve his life, rather than fitting into a gangster archetype. This casting choice made it harder to connect emotionally with the character's journey, as it overshadowed the depth of his struggles throughout the film.
Really beautiful movie!

Chiwetel Ejiofor brings to life the tragic story of Rob Peace. Even with a few imperfections in the production, Ejiofor navigates rough waters well with the help of good performances and ultimately the legacy Rob Peace.

As always, I feel compelled to leave an audience score because the critics on this site have only gotten worse over time.

This is a beautifully told true story about someone who, despite success after success, could never quite reach the light on the other side. For every achievement, there was always something pulling him two steps back. Yet, in the process and unfortunate passing he left behind a legacy—perhaps unintended and not the one he truly wanted, but remarkable nonetheless.

This is the beauty of storytelling and theater. Forget the critics—I think this was absolutely worth watching.
